EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This revision incorporates Revenue Procedure 2018-5. This revision incorporates Interim Guidance Memorandum TE/GE-07-0218-0008, Form 1024-A Application for Recognition of Exemption Under Section 501(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code dated February 2, 2018.
Declaratory Judgment Cases And The Administrative Record
Table of Contents
Judgment Cases And The Administrative 4.75.32

a. Knowing which cases are subject to declaratory judgement actions. b. Determining if a case ﬁle would require an administrative record. c. Determining how to maintain the administrative record. d. Knowing what documents are included in an administrative ﬁle. e. Properly preparing an index for an administrative record ﬁle.
Exempt Organizations Examination Procedures
Agents consult the Knowledge Management Network (K-Net) to ensure proper issue development and consistent application of the law.
The table lists commonly used acronyms and their deﬁnitions.

Acronym Deﬁnition EO Exempt Organizations AIMS Audit Information Management System K-NET Knowledge Management Network RAR Revenue Agent Report TAM Technical Advice Memorandum TE/GE Tax Exempt/Government Entities STAT NOTICE Statutory Notice of Deﬁciency PF Private Foundation NOL Net Operating Loss OCEP Office Correspondence Examina- tion Program
The instructions in this IRM apply to all audit cases subject to IRC

, declaratory judgment actions. These include audits in which proposes to either: a. Revoke an organization’s exempt status (qualiﬁcation). b. Modify an organization’s foundation status (classiﬁcation). These audit cases must include a separate and complete ﬁle: • Revocations (both agreed and unagreed) • Disqualiﬁcations (both agreed and unagreed) • Foundation Status modiﬁcation (both agreed and unagreed) Note: If the case is unagreed, an index is also required. Judgment Cases And The Administrative 4.75.32
A declaratory judgment action permits an organization to challenge a revoca- tion or foundation status modiﬁcation in court before the assessment of any:
Find the speciﬁc rules for declaratory judgment actions, including the content of the administrative record, in Tax Court Rules 210-218 at www.ustaxcourt.
Note: Large Business and International (LB&I) has audit jurisdiction over exempt farmers’ cooperatives described under IRC 521.
Exempt Organizations Examination Procedures

) A foundation status modiﬁcation (reclassiﬁcation) occurs when the IRS- determined qualiﬁcation or classiﬁcation is different than the foundation a. Originally claimed by the organization. b. Determined by either EO Rulings and Agreements or EO Examination. (

) Modiﬁcation of an organization’s foundation status occurs when the IRS mines, for example, that an organization is: a. A private non-operating foundation, though it claims to be or is currently classiﬁed as a public charity, or is currently classiﬁed as a private operating foundation. b. A private operating foundation, though it claims to be or is currently siﬁed as a public charity. c. An IRC
) organization, though it claims to be, or is currently siﬁed as, a IRC
) or IRC
) organization. d. An IRC
) organization, though it claims to be, or is currently siﬁed as, a IRC
) organization. e. An IRC
) organization, but it should be classiﬁed differently IRC
)(A) than it is currently classiﬁed; i.e., a IRC
)(A)(ii) school reclassiﬁed as a IRC
)(A)(vi) publicly-supported charity. (
) A determination subject to Section
also includes any organization that claims to be described in IRC
) that the IRS determines is not. (
) All revocations are treated the same (per the PATH Act of
), with tory judgment rights being conferred upon all revoked exempt organizations. Accordingly: a. All revocations of IRC
(c) or (d) organizations follow the same dures and processes as those previously used for IRC

) organizations. b. The IRS will revoke (or treat as revocation for declaratory judgement purposes) any organization that no longer qualiﬁes under the code section for which tax-exemption was granted or self-declared. c. This includes self-declarer organizations (Status

entities) determined not to qualify under the code section for which they ﬁled a return. Note: The self-declaring PF that has indicated on schedule A that they are a PF does not trigger a declaratory judgment action under IRC
That right would apply only upon a subsequent IRS exam. (
) The administrative record is the written record of the administrative proceed- ings between the IRS and the exempt organization. Record
(2) A foundation status modiﬁcation (reclassiﬁcation) occurs when the IRS- determined qualiﬁcation or classiﬁcation is different than the foundation

a. A private non-operating foundation, though it claims to be or is currently classiﬁed as a public charity, or is currently classiﬁed as a private operating foundation. b. A private operating foundation, though it claims to be or is currently clas- siﬁed as a public charity. c. An IRC
) organization, though it claims to be, or is currently clas- siﬁed as, a IRC

A determination subject to Section 7428 also includes any organization that claims to be described in IRC 170(c)(2) that the IRS determines is not.

The administrative record is the written record of the administrative proceed- ings between the IRS and the exempt organization.
ings between the IRS and the exempt organization. Tax Court Rule

) deﬁnes the administrative record as including: • The request for determination. • All documents the applicant submitted to the IRS as part of the determi- nation request. • All protests and related papers submitted to the IRS. • All written correspondence between the IRS and the applicant about those protests. • All pertinent returns ﬁled with IRS. • The notice of determination by the Commissioner.
Judgment Cases And The Administrative 4.75.32
page (

) Agents must include in the administrative record all documents exchanged between the IRS and the organization for audits on: a. Continuing qualiﬁcation (such as revocation of exempt status). b. Classiﬁcation (such as modiﬁcation of foundation status). (
) Although not documents, items such as electronic disks or all other media considered physical evidence and fall within the intent of Tax Court Rule

) when transmitted between the parties. If a disk is: a. Sent by letter, the disk is deemed part of that written document. b. Received at a conference, stamp and mark the disk appropriately, then reference it in a summary of the conference you send to the taxpayer. (
) For documents to be considered exchanged with the IRS, the material(s) go to or from the organization or its representative by: • Hand-delivery • Mail • Email • Fax
Agents must include in the administrative record all documents exchanged between the IRS and the organization for audits on:
Note: Don’t include documents reviewed on site in the administrative record unless the taxpayer gives you copies or you make copies for the exam ﬁles.
Caution: Don’t email Sensitive but Unclassiﬁed (SBU) information to the organiza- tion.
) The administrative record does not include any internally generated materials, such as: • Exam workpapers • AIMS documents (Forms
, or • IDRS prints • Reviewer memos (

) The administrative record does not include materials obtained from sources, such as: • Referral packages • Claims (normally not shared under any circumstances) • Summoned records from third parties • Summoned third-party testimony • Records obtained from city, county, state or federal agencies (

) You can include any document that is generated for internal use or a third-party in the administrative record by giving a copy of the the organization. For materials you obtained from outside sources, group manager and Area Counsel as to what parts of the document(s), you may share, and how to share them. (

) Any statements made in correspondence (by either side) is deemed there’s no conﬂicting or clarifying evidence. Therefore, if the or otherwise provides something that doesn’t appear to be correct, get
• Exam workpapers • AIMS documents (Forms
, or
) • IDRS prints • Reviewer memos

clariﬁcation. Conﬁrm clariﬁcation you receive by telephone either by the information in writing or by sending a letter which explains what was discussed on the phone. (
) It’s a best practice to create an administrative record ﬁle or folder at the beginning of every IRC
(c) and (d) audit. If you maintain the record ﬁle contemporaneously, it will be much easier to assemble after you ﬁnish the audit, and for Mandatory Review to review the case. (
) This ﬁle will contain all items exchanged between the IRS and the throughout the audit. (

) Keep the contents of this ﬁle in one of these locations until you determine outcome of the audit of exempt status (or foundation status): • An electronic folder or ﬁle • A box or paper folder • Combination of both (
) Record the date each document was exchanged. (

) Organize the administrative record ﬁle in chronological order, based on the documents were exchanged. The ﬁrst document exchanged is Exhibit and all succeeding information should follow accordingly. See Exhibit

) Typically, the ﬁrst document in the administrative record is the application, such as those below, with all of the original attachments bylaws, ﬁnancial statements, and expanded explanations of proposed ties) indexed as of the date the IRS received the application through to the date IRS issued the determination letter. • Form
, Application for Recognition of Exemption under section
) of the Internal Revenue Code • Form
, Application for Recognition of Exemption under section
(a) • Form
-A, Application for Recognition of Exemption under
) of the Internal Revenue Code. Exception: When organizations have claimed exemption without submitting an plication, the ﬁrst document is typically the earliest Form
clariﬁcation. Conﬁrm clariﬁcation you receive by telephone either by requesting the information in writing or by sending a letter which explains what was discussed on the phone.

Exception: When organizations have claimed exemption without submitting an ap- plication, the ﬁrst document is typically the earliest Form 990, Return of Organization Exempt From Income Tax, under audit.
You secure half of the year’s bank statements at the initial audit, a few more by IDR a month later, and the rest by bank summonses two months later. You subsequently exchange the summoned bank state

ments with the organization to include them in the administrative Counsel advises you to keep all bank statements for a given year together as one exhibit. Index the dates and methods describing the documents that were exchanged. Identify the number of pages of each set of documents in the description of the documents.
Judgment Cases And The Administrative 4.75.32
) See Exhibit
for a list of documents included in the administrative record, and instructions on how to index the documents into the record. (

) In general, if a document is related to the continuing qualiﬁcation or tion of an organization, and it’s a document that you haven’t exchanged of Documents the organization, mail, or otherwise provide a copy of the document to the ganization with a cover letter asking for any comments or clariﬁcation the organization may wish to provide. (
) Refer to Exhibit
for examples of documents which might not otherwise be included in the administrative record and for solutions for the documents or information included. (

) Even if a document is not related to an issue potentially subject to judgment relief, if it has been exchanged, include it in the administrative ﬁle with an explanation in the administrative record index. (

) Exchange a copy of the determination application you received from with the organization during the audit, and request comments as to any the changes in methods of operation from what was described in the (
) Get a copy of the determination application from the EO Files and Records as Part of Unit in Cincinnati. Ask the unit to ship, send a disc or secure email the in Unagreed (

) When exchanging the application with the organization, send only the documents labeled as public. Don’t send any PDF ﬁles listed as private because they are internal records that were never exchanged during the cation process. (
) If Cincinnati doesn’t have a copy of the determination, request it from the nization. (

) If you got the application from: a. Cincinnati and sent it to the organization, index it twice, (with any letter and enclosures) once at the start of the record, and again as of date you sent to the organization. b. The organization, index the application (and any cover letter and ments) only as of the date you received it because the document wouldn’t have been date stamped as of the initial application. Note: The organization’s copy of the application can’t be proven as being the conﬁrmed copy of the application.
Get a copy of the determination application from the EO Files and Records Unit in Cincinnati. Ask the unit to ship, send a disc or secure email the records.

Note: The organization’s copy of the application can’t be proven as being the true conﬁrmed copy of the application.
Prepare an index to the administrative record that will allow users to easily locate documents. Index each exhibit in order (i.e.,
, etc.). Generally, number tabbed folder dividers or write the corresponding number of each exhibit on a Post-It note affixed to the ﬁrst page of each document. In preparing the index, list:
Exempt Organizations Examination Procedures
a. The exhibits by number. b. A description of each document, including how it was exchanged, followed by the number of pages for each exhibit in parentheses. (
) Clearly describe all attachments to correspondence in the index. If it helps to clarify the index, give multiple attachments sub-numbers in an outline format (i.e.,

) If the organization ultimately agrees to revocation, disqualiﬁcation or a tion status modiﬁcation (in other words, you secure a Form
, Consent to Proposed Action), an administrative record is required, but an index is not. (

) Always track documents exchanged with the taxpayer and the dates the documents are exchanged. Be careful you don’t deface any documents (such Responsibility as making notes or highlighting text using highlight markers).
A description of each document, including how it was exchanged, followed by the number of pages for each exhibit in parentheses.

zation again, with the markings on it. Discuss this situation with your group manager or Area Counsel. (

(c) and audit upon indications of revocation and maintain it contemporaneously the revocation turns out to be agreed. An “agreed” case is one in which the taxpayer has communicated to the agent its agreement to the proposed by signing Form

agreement is not binding for cases subject to tory judgment, as the taxpayer may still exercise their declaratory rights under IRC
Form
is required to substantiate that the taxpayer has agreed to the proposed action. (

) When photocopying documents, make sure that the copy is a pristine identical copy of the original (aside from being in black and white versus color). This requires that you: a. Lay the document ﬂat on the glass pane in lieu of using an auto the document is folded or bent. b. Remove staples, paper clips, or other fasteners before copying. c. Copy the front and back of a document if information is present on the back. d. Check that no portions of the document are eliminated or missing in copy.

) By carefully tracking all documents exchanged by date, it’s easier to compile the administrative record and prepare the index if the case goes unagreed. imposes short deadlines for ﬁling the administrative record. Further, Counsel reviews all determinations subject to declaratory judgment before IRS issues the ﬁnal adverse letter. The administrative record must be well-organized and complete when Counsel receives it. (

Judgment Cases And The Administrative 4.75.32
Double check each page copied to ensure that it is a pristine identical copy of the original.
Note: When photocopying double-sided documents, create two single-sided one for the front, and one for the back.
Caution: Copies must be of high quality and resolution, as Counsel will redact the documents and submit copies of the redacted documents to court. The newer the copier, the better the result.
documents and submit copies of the redacted documents to court. newer the copier, the better the result. (
) When sending correspondence, date the letter with the actual date you fax or hand deliver it. (
) Staple a Form

A, TEGE Special Handling Notice, to the front of the folder or box. Write Administrative Record in the top margin and include following information on it: a. Organization’s name b. Organization’s TIN c. MFT d. Year(s) (
) Name the EO Administrative Record Index using the Reporting Case Management System (RCCMS), Naming Convention and save it in RCCMS Office Documents folder. (
) Do not deface documents you received from the organization in any way (writing, highlighting, noting or scribbling, etc.). If you need to write on a document, make a copy for that purpose. (

) Do not write the exhibit numbers from the “Administrative Record Index” the documents, other than via tabbed folder dividers or Post-It notes, Area Counsel prepares the ﬁnal index and will place the ﬁnal exhibit on the documents. (
) Date stamp documents and other items you received from the taxpayer on cover memo or ﬁrst page. Use the same date stamp the group secretary manager uses to stamp incoming mail. (
) Keep any “original” documents, such as original signed Forms
, Consent to Extend the Time to Assess Tax, and Forms
, Power Attorney and Declaration of Representative, in the workpaper ﬁle. Make for the administrative record ﬁle. (
) Outgoing correspondence and enclosures included in the administrative ﬁle will inevitably be copies, because you’ve already returned the originals the organization. (
) Verify copies for exactness against their originals including the same dates signatures. Make a copy of the signed letter before you mail it and keep copy in the administrative record ﬁle.
(01-18-2017) Documents Received from the Organization
Exempt Organizations Examination (

) Do not forget to make copies of enclosures or attachments you sent with respondence (or delivered by hand) and keep the copies in the record ﬁle. Note: If the case goes to litigation years later, it may be impossible to recreate missing attachments (which might include court cases, rulings, media articles, etc.) at a future date. (
) Copies must be identical to the correspondence or attachments you sent to taxpayer. In the opening appointment letter, for example, IRS Pub.
, Your Rights as a Taxpayer, must be enclosed. Include a photocopy or another printed version of the Pub.
provided to the taxpayer (same revision) in the administrative record ﬁle. (

) Clarify incorrect computations, misinterpretations of law (IRC, Regulations, Revenue Rulings, etc.) or incorrect conclusions in writing via subsequent spondence to the taxpayer. a. Any information you previously shared with the taxpayer becomes a of the administrative record; therefore, include incorrect information you put in writing and sent to the taxpayer/representative in the trative record. b. To correct a mistake, Do not remove the document from the tive record. Rather, acknowledge the mistake and send a corrected statement or revised calculation to the taxpayer/representative. (

) The CCR and other workpapers may contain details of conversations with officers or representative of an organization; however, these do not Communications part of the administrative record. Thus, it’s important to take steps to make information part of the administrative record. Do not refer to it in the agent’s report if it has not been made part of the administrative record. (
) To place information into the admin record that was communicated orally, create a transcript or summary of the discussion using Form
, Document Request, or Form

Before closing the case, we ship the audit case ﬁle and administrative a number of destinations. The case goes from:
The agent to the manager. The manager to Mandatory Review. Mandatory Review to Counsel. Counsel to Mandatory Review to issue the Final Adverse Determination Letter.

To ensure the administrative record is not lost or destroyed in transit, keep either an electronic scanned or hard copy of the ﬁle in the group.
The group manager (in consultation with Area Counsel) has discretion compliance with this requirement.

Exhibit 4.75.32-2 (01-18-2017) Documents that Are Part of the Administrative Record
How to include documents that should be part of the administrative
Users of efax will not have a cover sheet. Retrieve the efax from your Sent Items folder and a copy of the sent efax to place in the administrative record.
Make a copy of the letter at the time you faxed it showing the original signature as signed or stamped.
Print a copy of any enclosures such as information document requests, reports of audit, any forms, (such as waivers, agreement forms, statute extensions, etc.) and any publications.
When using efax, the efax transmittal e-mail you receive is also not part of the administrative record.
List the letter as of the date of the efax transmission in the admin record index.
the letter as of the date of the efax transmission in the admin record index.

Judgment Cases And The Administrative 4.75.32
Documents Not Included In the Administrative Record

If the CCR reﬂects information such as notes from a telephone call that are relied on in the decision process, create a transcript or summary of the dis- cussion and send it to the organization with a request for conﬁrmation or comment. Reduce the interview or conference to writing and provide a copy to the organization with a cover letter or Information Document Request (IDR) re- questing conﬁrmation of the contents. If hand- delivered to the organization with an IDR, ask the receiving person to acknowledge receipt by signing a copy of the IDR to be retained by the IRS. Provide copies of the newspaper articles to the organization with a cover letter or IDR requesting comments on the accuracy of the articles. If copies are sent by letter to the organization, send it certiﬁed. If hand-delivered to the organization with an IDR, ask the receiving person to acknowledge receipt by signing a copy of the IDR to be retained by the IRS. Be sure to attach copies of the newspaper articles to the copy of the IDR retained by the IRS. Note: For all documents secured from third parties and provided to the organization, be very careful to avoid disclosing a conﬁden- tial source or making an unauthorized disclosure. 4.75 Exempt Organizations Examination Procedures
To protect the identity of the former employee, make a written request for the organization to provide copies of the cancelled checks.
Copies of the organization’s cancelled checks provided to the agent by a former employee of the organization.
7. A copy of a rental agreement between the orga- nization and a related IRC 501(c)(3) organization for the use of the organization’s facilities provided to the agent by the related organization.
8. A letter sent to the Internal Revenue Service by the organization a week after the ﬁnal adverse de- termination letter was mailed to the organization.

9. Documents that substantiate the revocation and enhance the Service’s chances of sustaining the issue that were submitted to the Internal Revenue Service by a third party the day after a ﬁnal revo- cation letter was mailed to the organization.
Use either of two methods to include workpapers in the administrative record: (a) Mail a copy of the workpapers to the organiza

tion with a cover letter requesting comments. (b) Provide a copy of the original workpaper to the organization during the audit and request a receipt of acknowledgment. Caution: If shared, do not further modify the workpaper. If later modiﬁed, share the workpaper again.

Write to the taxpayer, reminding the taxpayer of what had been said, and note the failure to produce the documents. The letter with the er’s verbal representations and failures to produce is then part of the record. Of course, any written response from the taxpayer is also a part of the record.
